verse: When these events were completed, Jesus led His followers to Jerusalem where they would celebrate a Jewish feast together.
In Jerusalem they came upon a pool by the sheep gate surrounded by five covered porches. In Hebrew this place is called Bethesda.
From time to time, a heavenly messenger would come to stir the water in the pool. Whoever reached the water first and got in after it was agitated would be healed of his or her disease].
In the crowd, Jesus noticed one particular man who had been living with his disability for 38 years. He knew this man had been waiting here a long time.

At the moment Jesus uttered these words, a healing energy coursed through the man and returned life to his limbsâ€”he stood and walked for the first time in 38 years. But this was the Sabbath Day; and any work, including carrying a mat, was prohibited on this day.
The man genuinely did not know who it was that healed him. In the midst of the crowd and the excitement of his renewed health, Jesus had slipped away.
Some time later, Jesus found him in the temple and again spoke to him.
The man went immediately to tell the Jewish leaders that Jesus was the mysterious healer.
So they began pursuing and attacking Jesus because He performed these miracles on the Sabbath.

He was justifying the importance of His work on the Sabbath, claiming God as His Father in ways that suggested He was equal to God. These pious religious leaders sought an opportunity to kill Jesus, and these words fueled their hatred.
